title: Self-assembly: The power of organizing the unorganized - Skylar Tibbits

multiple-choice.question: What process allows unordered parts to come together in an organized structure on their own?

options.label: A
options.text: Replication

options.label: B
options.text: Transformation

options.label: C
options.text: Folding

options.label: D
options.text: Self assembly

multiple-choice.question: What drives proteins to self-assemble into 3-D structures?

options.label: A
options.text: Only the interaction between the amino acids along the chain

options.label: B
options.text: Only the relationship between the chain and the environment

options.label: C
options.text: Both the interaction between the amino acids along the chain and the relationship between the chain and the environment

options.label: D
options.text: Random forces

multiple-choice.question: What examples illustrate self-assembly in nature?

options.label: A
options.text: Snowflakes, galaxies, social networks, and the formations of cities

options.label: B
options.text: Galaxies and atomic interactions

options.label: C
options.text: Snowflakes and atomic interactions

options.label: D
options.text: Viruses and soccer balls

multiple-choice.question: How can self-assembly be used to create 3-D structures with DNA?

options.label: A
options.text: By using molecular microchips for computers

options.label: B
options.text: By designing a connection between the components like magnets and dumping them into a container

options.label: C
options.text: By creating many identical pieces that would come together to make a perfect sphere

options.label: D
options.text: By giving small, molecular elements the right conditions to form themselves into organized pathways

multiple-choice.question: What advantage does self-assembly offer in design and engineering?

options.label: A
options.text: Technologies become more reliant on fossil fuels

options.label: B
options.text: Technologies become less adaptive

options.label: C
options.text: Technologies become easier to build, more adaptive, and less reliant on fossil fuels

options.label: D
options.text: Technologies become more difficult to build

multiple-choice.question: What examples demonstrate self-assembly in the biological and chemical systems?

options.label: A
options.text: Proteins folding into 3-D structures, DNA replicating, and atomic interactions

options.label: B
options.text: DNA replicating only

options.label: C
options.text: Proteins folding into 3-D structures only

options.label: D
options.text: Neither proteins nor DNA

multiple-choice.question: How can self-assembly be used to create materials that can repair themselves?

options.label: A
options.text: By using molecular microchips for computers

options.label: B
options.text: By creating many identical pieces that would come together to make a perfect sphere

options.label: C
options.text: By designing a connection between the components like magnets and dumping them into a container

options.label: D
options.text: By using self-assembly as a new design, science, and engineering tool for making materials that can adapt and repair themselves

multiple-choice.question: What examples illustrate self-assembly in the chemical world?

options.label: A
options.text: Atomic interactions, cellular replication, and DNA

options.label: B
options.text: Cellular replication only

options.label: C
options.text: Atomic interactions only

options.label: D
options.text: Neither atomic interactions nor cellular replication

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential of self-assembly in the future?

options.label: A
options.text: Technologies become more reliant on fossil fuels

options.label: B
options.text: Technologies become less adaptive

options.label: C
options.text: Technologies become easier to build, more adaptive, and less reliant on fossil fuels

options.label: D
options.text: Technologies become more difficult to build

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Self-assembly is a process exclusive to the biological world

options.label: B
options.text: Self-assembly is a process exclusive to the chemical world

options.label: C
options.text: Self-assembly is a process that can be observed in various fields, including biology, chemistry, and technology

options.label: D
options.text: Self-assembly is not a real process

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a virus that self-assembles?

options.label: A
options.text: A protein with a specific sequence of amino acids

options.label: B
options.text: A soccer ball made up of identical sub-units with specific shapes

options.label: C
options.text: A DNA molecule with a specific sequence of nucleotides

options.label: D
options.text: A cell with a specific shape and structure

multiple-choice.question: How can self-assembly be used to create molecular microchips for computers?

options.label: A
options.text: By designing a connection between the components like magnets and dumping them into a container

options.label: B
options.text: By creating many identical pieces that would come together to make a perfect sphere

options.label: C
options.text: By using self-assembly as a new design, science, and engineering tool for making molecular microchips for computers

options.label: D
options.text: By using DNA replication

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the potential outcome when a group of people with diverse cognitive abilities work together to come up with creative ideas?

options.label: A
options.text: They will only come up with 10 ideas.

options.label: B
options.text: They will come up with a hundred useful ideas.

options.label: C
options.text: They will not be able to come up with any ideas.

options.label: D
options.text: They will come up with the same ideas as a group of people with similar cognitive abilities.

multiple-choice.question: Why are people attracted to others who think like them?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they want to challenge their own world view.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are seeking diverse perspectives.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it makes them feel smarter and validates their world view.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are looking for a competitive advantage.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential problem when people who think in the same way work together to solve complex problems?

options.label: A
options.text: They will be more confident in their solution.

options.label: B
options.text: They will come up with a better solution.

options.label: C
options.text: They will not get an uplift in collective intelligence.

options.label: D
options.text: They will not be able to solve the problem.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the potential consequence of surrounding yourself with people who think like you when solving complex problems?

options.label: A
options.text: You will become more confident in your solution.

options.label: B
options.text: You will get an uplift in collective intelligence.

options.label: C
options.text: You will become more confident about a solution that might be gravely mistaken.

options.label: D
options.text: You will not be able to solve the problem.

multiple-choice.question: What is the key feature of competitive advantage that the speaker believes will become important in the next 50 years?

options.label: A
options.text: Economic forecasting.

options.label: B
options.text: Problem-solving.

options.label: C
options.text: Innovation.

options.label: D
options.text: Cognitive diversity.

multiple-choice.question: Why is cognitive diversity important according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it leads to a lack of confidence in solutions.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it leads to a lack of collective intelligence.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it leads to a massive uplift in collective intelligence.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is not important.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the logical argument made by the economic forecaster?

options.label: A
options.text: If my model is the best one, then I should work with people who think differently.

options.label: B
options.text: If my model is the best one, then I should work with people who think like me.

options.label: C
options.text: If my model is the best one, then I should not work with anyone.

options.label: D
options.text: If my model is the best one, then I should work with people who think in a specific way.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential problem with the economic forecaster's logic according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: It is correct.

options.label: B
options.text: It is incorrect.

options.label: C
options.text: It is spectacularly wrong.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not a problem.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the pleasure experienced by the brain when people are telling us things we already suspect or believe?

options.label: A
options.text: Fear.

options.label: B
options.text: Anger.

options.label: C
options.text: Pleasure.

options.label: D
options.text: Surprise.

multiple-choice.question: Why is cognitive diversity important in the context of innovation according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it leads to a lack of creativity.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it leads to a lack of collective intelligence.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it leads to a massive uplift in collective intelligence.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is not important.
